monogr.title: A replie to M. Calfhills blasphemous answer made against the Treatise of the crosse, by Iohn Martiall, Bachiler of Lawe, and studient in diuinitie. Reade and regarde
monogr.author: Martiall, John

div.head: A REQVEST TO MAISTER GRINDAL AND OTHER SVPERINTENDENTS OF THE NEVVE CHVRCHE OF ENGLAND.
div.p:
AMONGEST other godly counsells of the wiseman this being one,Eccle. 19. that we should not beleue all that is said, I thought it not conueniēt to beleue the publick fame that reported vnto vs, that you M. Grindal did peruse the answer made to the Treatise of the Crosse, and allowe all the doctrine contayned in it, and priuiledge it to the printe, lest for my light beleauing you might with the same wise mā accōpte me light of heart. VVherfor as euery one that is desirous to lerne the truth, when rumors are spred inquireth of the authour as occasion serueth for furder triall and better creditte of the thinge: Euen so I longing to heare whether the doctrine vttred in the said booke, be the doctrine of all your church of Englād, or the fansie only of one idle brayne, make this request to you and the rest of your bretherne, for furder certificate, and surer knowledg of this. For albeit the wynkīg at the setting forth of it, the permitting it to be sold, the suffring the authour to triūphe of it at the Crosse, and the not forewarning the people to be ware of it, and longe silence to maister Dormans request,M. Dorma in the preface. haue ministred vehement presumptiōs both of liking and allowing, yet haue I not adiuged it reason, to chardge the whole congregation with it, vnlesse I haue some furder notice and certificate
from you. As you therfore tender the honour of God, truth of the Ghospell, and wealth of their soules, whome you pretend to bring to Christ: So let vs be aduertised whether you will iustifie all the doctrine vttred in that boke, as the receaued and approued doctrine of all your newe church of England or no. The request is reasonable: yf you refuse it, we shall iudge of your silence accordingly.

Lest you should hafte in this cause, and finde some friuolous excuse, as distemperature at the full of the mone, businesse in ministring of othes, care in sending promoters to the hauens, aegernesse in searching after bokes, and trouble in seeking after non communicants, and zeale to apease the contētions amongest the brotherhoode for the weightie matters lately in hand, and pretend that you haue no leysure to take a newe viewe of that old worke, I haue drawē out certayne of his positions, and quoted the places in the margent, where you shall finde them. And as I truly in effect repete them: So doe I most earnestly require and challenge you and all the rest of the superintendents (that must be ready to geue an accompte of their doctrine to al that aske) to geue notice and signification by some pamphlet in print, whether it be the receaued and approued doctrine of all the newe church of England able to be iustified by the playne and vndoubted word of God,M. Calfhills positions. and by the true and godly fathers of the church, and generall councells within six hundred yeres after Christ, or when the Ghospell was most sincerely preched.
Fol. 3. aThat straunge attire, difference of meate, refusal of marriadge, rysing at midnight, making of vowes, shutting vp in cloyster, and most wilfull beggery, be ordinances of the diuell.
Fol. 32. bThat faith forceth synne vpon vs.
Fol. 35. aThat a naked faith is able to teache hym that neither did nor euer could heare, without any further information that a God there is.
Fol. 124. bThat Latin seruice, vowing of chastitie, communicating vnder one kinde, are direct contrary to the woorde.

Fol. 135. •
That God commaunded Christ only, no church, no councell,
no man to be heard.

That they made a good excuse that denying the bodie of Polycarpe to the Christians that sued for it,Fol. 147. b saied it should not be delyuered, lest they would forsake Christ, and begynne to woorship hym.
That God saied of Behemoth and Leuiathan,Fol. 27. a none dare come neare them, none can resiste them.
That neuer God, nor good man deuised a crosse.Fol. 170. a
That we hauing the material crosse can not come to the knowledge of the crucified.Fol. 18. b
That crossing bread such inconueniēce that the externall actiō had still in reuerence, the inward faith hath ben vntaught.Fol. 26. a

That whersoeuer a signe of the crosse was,Fol. 25. b we should not thīk that there was a zeale of true deuotion, but as wel, or rather an heathenish obseruāce, and superstition of them that neuer thought vpon Christ.
That the signe of the crosse was made a magical inchauntemēt and cause of conquest against the Christians.Ibidem. b.
That the crosse was neuer receaued vpon good occasion.Fol. 26. a
That the crosse is not the signe peculiar to Christians.Fol. 51. b.
That the crosse is likened to the helmet of hel and coniurers mace.Fol. 29. b
That the diuel seemeth to tremble at the signe of the crosse for no other purpose,Fol. 29. a. but that we should leaue our confidence in Christ, and only repose it in a piece of wood.
That the diuel delited in the signe of the crosse.Fol. 117. a.
That more witchcraft, ād sorcery,Fol. 90. b was done by the signe of the crosse, than with any thing in the world beside.
That prayer for the dead is a thing of naught.Fol. 36. b
That suffrages, intercessions to Sainctes,Fol. 94. a. and Masses are helps to hel.
That it is a generall precept, all men to iudge, al men to trie,Fol. 23. b what doctrine ethey receaue.
That Sainctes honoured with the honour of inuocation,Fol. 26. a are diuels.
That no spirite can be woorse, than he, that hath no faith.Fol. 36. a.
Fol. 52. aThat to dedicate a church in the honour of a sainct, is a derogation to Gods honour, and contrary to the vse of the primitiue church.
Fol. 53. bThat it is a poynt most strange and dissonant from al godly lerning to say, that Mary mother of Christ did make a vowe of chastitie.
Fol. 103. bThat there be not seuen graces of the holy Ghost, mentioned in the 11. of Esai: or that to gather a seuēfold grace out of that chapiter, is to absurde.
Ibidem b.That the Papistes saying there be seuē graces of the holy Ghost, be falsifiers of the scriptures.
Fol. 106. aThat the Masse is nothing els but the sacrifice of the diuel.
Fol. 113. b.That anoynting mentioned by S. Iames was temporal, and only touched the present state.
Fol. 107. aThat to blesse and geue thankes is all one.
Fol. 105. bThat neither scripture nor any lerned father commendeth any blessing, but of prayer vnto vs.
Fol. 86. aThat Helena for going to Hierusalem and seeking the crosse, was superstitious.Fol. 132. a
Fol. 101. bThat S. Dionise and Fabian (both holy martyrs) were, the on suspected, the other infamous.
Fol. 103. aThat S. Cyprians saying, vngi necesse est eum qui baptisatus sit, etc. It is necessary for hym that is baptised to be anoynted, was proude and blasphemous.
Fol. 36. aThat it was blasphemie for S. Gregorie to report howe a Iewe was preserued from sprites by the signe of the crosse.

Fol. 68. aThat the seuenth general councell, was a doltish and proude Synode,Fol. 160. b an insolent and doltish conspiracie: A Nice councel, and the fathers a madde company,Ibidem a reuerend asses, Synodical men,Fol. 17. a Nice masters, and their decrees idolatrous dedes and doctrines, and impudent vanities.
Fol. 141. bThat the councel of Elibery or Granata in Spayne was a general councel.
Fol. 145. bThat we making our prayers to sainctes retayne the memorie of the dead, and call vpon the dead.

Fol. 3 aThat the Papistes haue the decrees and decretalls in as soueraigne
a price as the Bible.
That the bloud of Christ amongest the catholiques (whome he calleth a rable of Romish heretikes) is a thing of a thousand lest accompted of.Fol. 94. a
That ceremonies were vsed in dedication of churches,Fol. 95. a to bring in the diuell.
That within twoe hundred yeres after Christ the simplicitie of Gods ordinances was refused.Fol. 96. a
That the fathers in obseruances and ceremonies scant agreing with them selues,Fol 2. 3. a declined all from the simplicitie of the Ghospel.

That sithens Siluesters tyme (which was in the yere of our lord 309.Fol. 85. b) such filth of idolatrie and superstition flowed into the most partes of all Christendome, out of the synck of Rome, that he needed as many eies as Argus, that should haue espied any piece of sinceritie vntill the miscreants, and heretikes, to witte Luther and Crammer, beganne to restore the decaied state.Fol. 85. b
That Rome is the synagog of Satan, synke of idolatrie,Fol. 121. b and no membre of the church.Fol, 152. a
That the Pope is the greate Antichrist of Rome.Fol. 87. b
That Popery is worse idolatrie than the Iewes.Fol. 133. a.
That yf we light tapers in the day for the vse and seruice of God, it is blasphemous.Fol. 142. b.
That there is no lauful president of any miracle done by the signe of the crosse.Fol. 151. a
That euery citie, euery monasterie,Fol. 153. b euery priuate parish church in Christendom, hath some piece of the holy crosse.
That king Salomon was abused by images.Fol. 165. a.
That these woordes, Iacob summitatem virgae Ioseph adorauit, Fol. 70. a Iacob woorshipped the toppe of Iosephs rodde, was coyned of a father in the coūcel of Nice, and not to be foūde in scripture.
That this woorde, Crux, signifieth a crosse piller, a candelstick,Fol. 79. a a staffetorche, or a pole that carieth the cresset.Fol. 139. b.
That the ordering of ministres is a sacrament,Fol. 104. b. and yet no sacrament of the church.
Fol. 99. a.That Imposition of hādes (which he calleth a signe) should not remayne.
Fol. 111. b.That it is blasphemous and abhominable to call penaūce the seconde table or borde after shipwrack.
Ibidem b.That it is an horrible lawe not only impious to God, but also iniurious to man, that he that diuorceth an adulterous person, may not marry another.
Ibidem b.That it is an horrible lawe not only impious to God, but also iniurious to man, that youngefolke wilfully contracting them selues without their parents cōsent, may marry wel ynough.

Fol. 51. b.That it accordeth not with the doctrine of Christ, to say: Virtutū opes habere non possunt qui voluerint diuitias habere terrenas, they can not haue the substance of vertues, that will haue the substance of the earth.
Fol. 120. a.Or that the thing (which was the holy Ghost) geuen by imposition of handes in the Apostles tyme, is nowe abolished.
Fol. 99. a.Or that Chat Christ is not Legislator a lawemaker, and not catholique to call hym so.

These with diuerse other which I omitte to repete, are his positions and paradoxes, these are his resolutions and sayings, as you may see in the places quoted in the margent. Nowe yf you haue priuiledged and allowed them as the receaued and approued doctrine of all the newe church of England, for them and euery one of them we require proufe out of the playne and vndoubted worde of God, out of the true and godly fathers of the church, within six hundred yeres after Christ, and out of lauful councells, within the said terme, or within these xiiij. hundred yeres. And that the world may see your playne dealing in this behalf, Ley downe the scriptures plainly without corruption, ley downe the fathers wordes truly without falsifying. Ley downe the canons of the councells simply without all clipping, chaunging and inuerting their wordes. Or yf you haue neither scriptures, nor fathers, nor councells for proufe of them, condemne them as blasphemous, wicked, and vngodly, able to be mayntayned neither by scripture, councell, nor any
godly fathers of the church. Yf you suffer this doctrine to procede and haue increase, as it is sowed, we may say vnto you, as the vertuous emperour Cōstātine saied to the Arriās assembled at a Synode in Tyrus: Lib. 3. cap. 7. histor. Tripart. Vos autem qui sancta mysteria eius clementiae proferre videmini, non dicam custodire, vos inquam nihil agitis nisi quae ad contentionem noscuutur & odia pertinere, & vt absolute dicam, quae ad humani generis tendere videntur interitum. You who seeme to bring foorth, I will not say keepe the mysteries of his mercie, you I say, doe nothing but that which is knowen to pertayne to contention and debate, and seme to tende, (that I may speake fully and wholy as it is) to the destruction of all man kinde. Or yf you fansie not Constantines saying, I will say vnto you as that valiaunt Emperour Charles the fyft sayed of Luther in his edicte set forth at VVormes in this sort: Lutherus scribit nihil ferè aliud, nisi quod ad seditionem, schisma, bellum, caedes, rapinas, incendia, & ad defectionem vniuersalem Christiana fidei tendit atque subseruit: Luther writeth almost nothing els, but that which tendeth and serueth to sedition, schisme, batail, slaughter, robberies, burnings, and to the generall reuolt and defection of the Christiann faith. Or yf that like you not, we will say of you as our noble king, Henry of famous memorie spoke of the same friers faction. Nulla vnquam factio fuit ita seditiosa, Pestilens, nepharia, Epist. ad duces Saxo. quae sic religionem omnem tollere, leges omnes ob • ilere, mores omnes bonos corrumpere, res publicas omnes euertere, machinata fit, vt nunc ista coniuratio Lutherana. There was neuer factiō so seditious, so pestilēt, so wicked, which so endeuored to take away all religion, to oppresse all Lawes, to corrupt all good manners as this conspiracie of the Lutherans doth nowe. The counsells of Christe in his Ghospel, to be called ordinances of the diuell, suffrages helpes to hel, The lawe of God and his church forbidding hym that diuorceth an adulterous {per}son to marry another whiles the partie lyueth, horrible and impious, the prayers of Christians a sacrifice of the diuel, Christ no lawe maker, and his Ghospel no Lawe, what is to endeuour to bring a generall reuolt and defection from all Christian religion and faith, yf this be not Grindall? Consider it, you were best. The matter is weightie, and the tyme perilous.
And whereby a figure called praeoccupatio, you chardge vs that our bokes are seditious, yf it may please you to examine them indifferently, it will easely be espied whether your diuines bokes breathe sedition, or ours. Let the lerned iudge: praysed be God, There is no blast blowen against the monstruous regimēt of womē. There is no libel set foorth for order of successiō: there is no word vttred agaīst dewe obediēce to the soueraine.

As for corrupt gaynes which is another foule fault that you chardge vs withall, we are thankes be to God so farre from all iust reproufe in this behalf, that euer more we were content to geue the copies of our bokes and gaynes whatsoeuer it were, to him that would bare the chardges of the print, and conuey them into the realme. And as yet, yf it will please you either to send vs mony to bare such necessarye charges, or apoynt some frend of yours that will faithfully print and trulye set them foorth to the sight of the worlde, you and your factour shall haue all the gaynes, that may be made. At this present I haue gathered together maister Calfhils lies, contradictions, false translations, falsifying the scriptures, corrupting the doctours, which will make a pretie volume, and because I could not conueniently set them foorth together with this replie, I haue reserued them to another tyme. Nowe yf it wil please you to trie whether I wil stād to the performāce of my promise, send your factour with your lettre and he shall be heard with the conditions afore mentioned. S. Augustine declaring certayne properties of the hartes in the forest,In Psa. 41 saieth: They rūne very swift to the foūtaynes ād ryuers, they kil serpēts, and after the killing of thē are very thyrstie, and when they will swymme ouer into any other cuntrie, they ley their hornes one vpon another: and applying that to vs, he saieth: Sic nos Christiani debemus velociter currere ad fontes aquarum, & vitia, serpentes iniquitatis nostrae interimere, vt amplius desideremus fontes veritatis: Debemus inuicem onera portare & sic adimplere legem Christi. So we Christen men ought to runne swiftely to the fountaynes of water, and kill synnes, the serpentes of our iniquitie, that we may the more desire the fountaynes of truthe, we ought to beare one anothers burden, and
so fulfill the lawe of Christ. Nowe yf your zeale be such as you pretend to the Christen religion, and furderance of truth geue vs leaue to runne to the fountaynes of water, to kill the serpents of iniquitie, to impugne your heresies, to detect your ministers lies, keepe not our bookes from them, that would come to the fountaynes of truthe, but as you loue the truth, so beare part of the burden with vs, and fulfill the lawe of Christ. God send you his grace, and spirite of truth.

div.head: TO THE NEVVE CLERGIE.

p.hi: Deponentes mendacium loquimini veritatem vnusquisque cum proximo suo, quia sumus inuicem membra, Ephes. 4.

div.p: Leying away all lying speake the truth, euery man to his neighbour, for as much as we are membres one of another.
